title: Stonehouse Walks

images.title: Peter Kwan / Stonehouse High Street
images.caption: Stonehouse High Street. Taken from the Post Office looking south. You can see the junction of Regent Street and on the left a little way down the road is the spire of a church.

images.title: Looking towards Stonehouse Bridge along the Stroudwater Canal,Stonehouse by Jaggery, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking towards Stonehouse Bridge along the Stroudwater Canal

images.title: Derek Harper / Doverow Hill
images.caption: Doverow Hill. Doverow Hill overlooks Stonehouse on the west; this is the northeastern side, where it slopes down towards Stroud, and the Cotswold Way crosses not far behind the camera.

images.title: Cotswold Way into the Severn Vale-Randwick, Glos by Martin Richard Phelan, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Nutshell House and Nutshell Bridge, Stroudwater Canal, Stonehouse by Jaggery, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Nutshell House and Nutshell Bridge, Stroudwater Canal, Stonehouse

description: This Cotswolds village is located in a rural spot just to the east of Stroud . This walk from the village takes you to the peaceful woodland trails in Standish Wood before climbing to the viewpoint at Haresfield Beacon . The route uses a section of the Cotswold Way National Trail which can be picked up just to the east of the village and the train station. The trail will take you north past Doverow Hill, Westrip and Randwick before entering Standish Wood where there's bluebells in the spring and evidence of Bronze Age settlements. From here you can head a short distance north to Haresfield Beacon where there's an Iron Age Hillfort and wonderful views over the Severn Vale. Towards the end of the route there's also a pleasant waterside stretch along the Stroud Canal which runs just to the south of the settlement.
